case_name: Canara Industrial and Banking Syndicate Limited and Canara Bank Limited v. Their Employees

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 787 and 731-752 of 1962 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 787 and 731-752 of 1962. Appeals by special leave from the order dated March 16, 1962, and Februa

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from orders dated March 16, 1962 and February 14, 1962 of Central Government Labour Court at Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the order dated March 16, 1962, and February 14, 1962 of the Central Government Labour Court at Delhi in L. C. As. Nos. 212 of 1962 and 869-88 and 937-945 of 1961 respectively.

facts.text: Central Government Labour Court at Delhi passed orders in L.C. Nos. 212 of 1962, 869-88 and 937-945 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Central Government Labour Court at Delhi in L. C. As. Nos. 212 of 1962 and 869-88 and 937-945 of 1961 respectively.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 22, 1963 by WANCHOO J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. April 22. The judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO J.- These appeals by special leave arise from the orders

facts.text: Appeals Nos. 731 to 752 by Canara Industrial and Banking Syndicate Limited.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals by special leave arise from the orders of the Central Government Labour Court, Delhi, and will be dealt with together as they raise the same point. Appeals Nos. 731 to 752 arc by the Canara Industrial and Banking Syndicate Limited while Appeal No. 787 is by the Canara Bank Limited.

facts.text: Appeal No. 787 by Canara Bank Limited.

anchor.surface_text: 752 arc by the Canara Industrial and Banking Syndicate Limited while Appeal No. 787 is by the Canara Bank Limited.

facts.text: Employees filed applications under s. 33C(2) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, allowed by tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: In all these appeals there were applications by the employees of the two banks under s. 33-C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act, No.14 of 1947, hereinafter referred to as the Act , which have been allowed by the tribunal.

facts.text: Respondent is a clerk employed by Canara Bank at Bandra branch since October 1953.

anchor.surface_text: We shall give the facts in appeal No. 787 in detail. The respondent in that appeal is a clerk employed by the bank at its Bandra branch and has been working there since his appointment in October 1953.

facts.text: Respondent claimed Rs. 15/- per month special allowance under para 164(b)(7) of Sastry Award.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent claimed that he was entitled to a special allowance of Rs. 15/- per month admissible to cashiers in-charge of cash in pay offices in accordance with para 164 b (7) of the All India Industrial Tribunal (Bank Disputes) Award, popularly known as the Sastry award .

facts.text: Respondent worked as cashier in-charge at Worli and Bandra branches, sole charge of cash, receiving and paying.

anchor.surface_text: He further claimed that he worked as cashier in-charge of cash at Worli and Bandra branches of the bank and was entrusted with the sole charge of handling cash as there was nobody else to assist him. He was doing the work both of receiving and paying and was solely responsible in respect thereof to the bank.

facts.text: Bank resisted claim: application not entertainable under s.33C(2), no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The bank resisted the claim of the respondent and its case was firstly that such an application was not entertainable under s. 33-C(2) of the Act and the labour court had no jurisdiction to decide it,

facts.text: Bank contended respondent not at pay office, not entitled under Sastry award para 164(b)(7).

anchor.surface_text: secondly that the respondent was working at a branch and not at a pay office and therefore was not entitled to any special allowance under para 164 b (7) of the Sastry award,

facts.text: Bank contended respondent not cashier in-charge, merely routine clerk.

anchor.surface_text: and thirdly that in any case the respondent cannot be said to be a cashier in- charge of cash at the branch where he was working and therefore was not entitled to any allowance.

facts.text: Labour Court found respondent doing combined work of receiving and paying cash, entitled to allowance.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal went into the evidence as to the duties of Shri N. Surkanand respondent and found that the respondent was doing the combined work of both receiving and paying cash.

facts.text: Respondent Anant Narayan Surkan was sole paying and receiving clerk in branch, no other clerk in cash department.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the respondent, Anant Narayan Surkan, was the sole paying and receiving clerk in the banks branch and there was no other clerk working in the cash department.

facts.text: Bank manual describes procedure: strong-room opened by Agent and second key-holder.

anchor.surface_text: The manual of instructions issued by the bank shows exactly what the procedure is in the matter of dealing with cash. According to this manual, at the commencement of the days business, the bank. strong-room is opened by the Agent and the second key-holder who are in joint charge with independent keys, of what may be called the double lock.

facts.text: Shroff (paying-cum-receiving clerk) handles cash from single lock box.

anchor.surface_text: The amount so withdrawn is taken by the shroff i. e. paying-cum-receiving clerk . The box containing the shroffs overnight cash balance (single lock) is also taken out of the strong-room and is handed over to the shroff, who is to count the balance in the single lock box when receiving it in the morning.

facts.text: At end of day, Agent takes over cash from shroff.

anchor.surface_text: At the close of the days business, the Agent takes over the cash held by the shroff. The cash under single lock is also to be checked in the presence of the shroff.

facts.text: Court held application under s.33C(2) maintainable, citing Central Bank of India v. P.S. Rajgopalan.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether such an application under s. 33C(2) of the Act was entertainable by the labour court and whether that court had jurisdiction to decide it has been considered by this Court in Central Bank of India Limited v. P. S. Rajgopalan .

facts.text: Shri Jeejeebhoy clarified in 1959 that 'pay office' includes branches.

anchor.surface_text: but the question whether the provision of para 164 b (7) would apply to a branch was referred to Shri jeejeebhoy for clarification under s. 6 of the Industrial Disputes (Banking Companies) Decision Act, 1955, and Shri Jeejeebhoy held in 1959 that the use of the words pay office was not intended to have a restricted meaning referring only to those units which actually had the designation of pay office and would also apply to a branch in proper circumstances.

facts.text: In appeals 731-752, sole clerk keeps key of single lock box.

anchor.surface_text: There is no evidence in appeal No. 787 as to who keeps the key of the single lock box, though in the other group of appeals where also the facts are similar, we have the further evidence that the key of the single lock box is kept by the paying-cum-receiving clerk,

facts.text: Court found sole receiving-cum-paying clerk in-charge of cash in single lock during day.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that when cl. (7) of para 164 b uses the words cashiers in-charge it refers to charge of cash in the single lock and not charge of cash in the double lock, and it is in that view that we have to see whether the workmen concerned in the present appeals were in-charge of cash in the single lock.

facts.text: Clerks take charge of single lock box in morning, responsible throughout day.

anchor.surface_text: the evidence in the present cases shows that the clerks concerned take charge of the single lock box first thing in the morning. Each of them is the sole clerk in the cash department doing both receiving and paying out cash throughout the day when the bank is open and makes over charge of the single lock box at the end of the day

facts.text: Court held such sole clerks entitled to special allowance under para 164(b)(7).

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances these clerks must be held to be cashiers in-charge of cash in a branch and as the words Pay offices used in cl. (7) have been clarified as including a branch these cashiers would be entitled to the special allowance mentioned in cl. (7) .

Appeals by special leave from the order dated March 16, 1962, and February 14, 1962 of the Central Government Labour Court at Delhi in L. C. As. Nos. 212 of 1962 and 869-88 and 937-945 of 1961 respectively.
The judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO J.- These appeals by special leave arise from the orders
s. 33-C  2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, No.14 of 1947,  hereinafter referred to as the Act , which have been allowed by the tribunal.

holdings.text: An application under s. 33C(2) of the Act is maintainable by the labour court which has jurisdiction to decide it

anchor.surface_text: The question whether such an application under s. 33C(2) of the Act was entertainable by the labour court and whether that court had jurisdiction to decide it has been considered by this Court in Central Bank of India Limited v. P. S. Rajgopalan . It has been held there that an applic

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedent from Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P.S. Rajgopalan holding such applications maintainable

holdings.text: Para 164(b)(7) of the Sastry award applies to branches as 'pay office' includes branches in proper circumstances per authoritative clarification

anchor.surface_text: We are further of opinion that there is no force in the second contention of the banks either. It is true that para 164 b (7) of the Sastry award speaks of cashiers in-charge of cash at pay offices. We recognise that strictly speaking a branch of the bank is not the same thing as a

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts clarification by Shri Jeejeebhoy (tribunal chairman) under s.6 Industrial Disputes (Banking Companies) Decision Act 1955 as authoritative and unchallenged since 1959

holdings.text: 'Cashiers in-charge of cash' in cl.(7) of para 164(b) refers to charge of cash in the single lock during business hours, not double lock

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that when cl. (7) of para 164 b uses the words cashiers in-charge it refers to charge of cash in the single lock and not charge of cash in the double lock, and it is in that view that we have to see whether the workmen concerned in the present appeals

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on bank manual procedures for cash handling; overall double lock charge with Agent irrelevant; harmonises with Jeejeebhoy clarification and avoids making it useless

holdings.text: Sole receiving-cum-paying clerks in branch cash departments who handle single lock cash throughout business day are cashiers in-charge entitled to special allowance under para 164(b)(7)

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances these clerks must be held to be cashiers in-charge of cash in a branch and as the words Pay offices used in cl. (7) have been clarified as including a branch these cashiers would be entitled to the special allowance mentioned in cl. (7) .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show sole clerks take charge of single lock morning to evening; higher duties/responsibilities than routine clerks per para 140 Labour Appellate Tribunal; cls 3-6 distinguish multi-clerk units
